article.description: Kyle Korver scored 23 points and No. 15 Creighton pulled away to an 84-63 victory over Drake on Sunday.
article.headline: Korver's 23 points spark No. 15 Blue Jays
article.linkText: Creighton rebounds from first loss to defeat Drake
article.story: OMAHA, Neb. (AP) -- For about five minutes Sunday, Drake threatened to make a game out of an apparent blowout. Then No. 15 Creighton reverted to the form it had shown during its best start in 60 years and pulled away to an 84-63 victory. After leading 48-30 at halftime, Creighton (11-1, 2-0 Missouri Valley Conference) saw the Bulldogs go on a 13-2 run to pull within 55-47. "They came out and ran their stuff, and defensively we were soft,'' Creighton coach Dana Altman said. "They got shots they wanted, buried them, and it became a game.'' It wasn't for long, though. Kyle Korver drilled a 3-pointer to start a 17-0 Creighton run that put the game out of reach. The Bluejays forced three turnovers, center Brody Deren blocked two shots and Korver blocked another, and Drake (5-8, 0-2) went scoreless for almost nine minutes during the game's decisive stretch. The Bluejays outscored Drake 26-7 over 13 minutes to stretch their lead to 81-54. "Probably the best 13 minutes defensively we've played in a long, long time,'' Altman said. "Brody protected the basket really well, we were up in the passing lanes. That's what this team needs. We need to guard. We're dependent way too much on our jump-shooting ability and not the defensive stops.'' Korver, coming off a career-high 32 points in a loss to No. 19 Xavier, made his first five shots and finished 7-of-9 from the field. DeAnthony Bowden and Mike Grimes each added 11 points for the Bluejays. Greg Danielson had 14 points and 11 rebounds for Drake, while Luke McDonald and J.J. Sola each had 13 points. Creighton led by as many as 21 points in a first half that saw the teams combine for 26 fouls and 27 turnovers. "You go on the road, and you expect to be ugly sometimes,'' Deren said. "You don't expect it at home, though. It really disrupted our rhythm.'' Creighton had leads of 15-2, 19-5 and 28-8 before Grimes made two free throws to give the Bluejays their biggest lead of the half, 40-19. Drake committed 17 of its 22 turnovers and shot 38.5 percent in the first 20 minutes. Creighton, meanwhile, shot 61.5 percent in taking its 18-point halftime lead. David Newman hit two 3-pointers and McDonald had one as the Bulldogs made their run at the Bluejays early in the second half. In their last meeting, Drake beat the Bluejays in Omaha to deny them the outright regular-season Missouri Valley Conference championship. Sunday's game was Creighton's first since the 75-73 loss at Xavier last Tuesday. "Our motivation for this game was to just get better,'' Bowden said. "We don't worry about the rankings. Who cares about the rankings? It's good we're ranked, and we deserve it. But a couple losses, and we'll be out.''
